author: David Bush

comments.message: I really like this idea because it actually works and is proven.  Is the liquid easy to transport; does it need to be kept cryogenicaly frozen?  What would be a rough price for a system?

1. Liquid air can be transported from either US or Europe in large Dewars.2. There are plants in West Africa that make liquid Nitrogen and Liquid Oxygen.  It could be sourced locally and mixed.3. We have a portable storage and manufacturing station design that we hope to prototype and test soon.  Plug this unit in and it will make Liquid air from ambient air.The price of the system depends on how you implement.  Hoseline would be the cheapest, SCBA type pack would be more expensive.  It is certainly more expensive and complex than the current solution, but it allows workers to work longer and provides better protection --> happy workers--> more workers.Also, the system would be reusable.  The idea would be to use as much off the shelf products.  There are encapsulated Level B suits that would work for $200, then add either the hoseline system or the Liquid Air SCBA packs.

description:
History
NASA has used cryogenic liquid air for many years to support ground operations.  Primarily in either crew rescue or in hazmat roles.  The technology provides both air and cooling to the user.  The technology has been proven operationally for many years.  It has several "form factors":  SCBA like demand based mask/pack without suit, protective suit fed via hoseline, or protective suit with 2 hr recirculating air pack for autonomy.  While very safe and reliable, the technology has not gone commercial for a variety of reasons.  In 2011 we were approached by NIOSH to develop new cryogenic life support technologies based on the existing sytems to provide emergency egress and rescue life support systems for mines.  Under this cooperative program we have adressed many of the technical issues with the older generation of cryogenic life support equipment and made prototypes to demonstrate the concepts.  We feel that the technology level is nearly ready for commercialization.  It would be ideal for this type of situation.

Propsals
We have three leading concepts that we feel could be beneficial in combating the Ebola outbreak:
1. Use current 2 hr recirculating packs (ECU) in off the shelf Level A suits.  These packs provide cooling and autonomous operation.  We have some ECUs available now, and we have a working relationship with the manufacturer.  They could begin manufacturing these again.
2. Use hoseline fed Level A suits in appropriate situations.  These suits can either be fed with compressed gas (traditional but hot) or liquid air (provides cooling for hot environments).  This has the advantage of indefinite operations and cooling.
3. Use a 1 hr demand based (mask) pack with either a Level A suit or a encapsulated Level B suit.  The system provides cool air to the face of the user and when the pack is encapsulated under the suit, it takes the heat it needs to vaporize the air from the users environment, thus providing cooling to the body.  The 1 hr pack is light enough that it shouldn't encumber the user, and it has a Quick Disconnect (QD) on the side that allows it to be refilled quickly while the user is still breathing on it.  In this concept the user would be untethered, cooled, and could operate indefinitly with periodic refills.  A partnership with a suit manufacturer would have to be developed to customize the fill port penetration, but it is certainly feasible.
summary: NASA has used liquid air based life support equipment to support the space program for many years.  We deal with hot (think Florida in summer) dangerous (think highly toxic fuels) environments on a regular basis.  Vaporization of liquid air, to provide breathing air,  requires heat.  The heat can be taken from the worker to provide effective cooling.  The technology can be used in a variety of different ways depending on the specific need.  Some aspects of this technology could be made available on a limited scale almost immediately (gear leftover from Space Shuttle program).
title: Adapt NASA liquid air life support technology to both protect medical personnel and provide relief from heat stress.
